To Debbie R., # 27:

I do so enjoy your posts here, Debbie, but I have to point out that your arithmetic is a bit faulty. With all the zeros, billions and trillions flying around it is easy to lose perspective, but you have your percentages off by a factor of 10. What is a factor of ten or a billion or $100,000,000 mean in the big picture anyway? As I said above, it is not real money, it is only taxpayer money. We can always print or tax away more.

It would seem that you consider the loss of $500,000,000 from fraud in one year, in one city through only one fraudulent vehicle to be an acceptable loss. I admit that I never heard that argument before. Perhaps you could write that up and get other advocates of the Senate plan to use that as one of their talking points when promoting their position. That would be very helpful to everyone.

Disappointed, #18 above makes an excellent point about the title and the short summary for Professor Reinhardt's essay. The professor's essay doesn't actually say anywhere that the fraud losses in health care are small. He observes only that he doesn't believe fraud on a substantial scale occurs in major hospitals. He is surely correct about that, but he never extrapolates that thesis to health care overall, no matter what the subtitle says. I am going to go out on another limb and guess that Professor Reinhardt, makes no such extrapolation and that he knows better. He will surely saw one of these limbs off in a post one day, but I will take my chances until then.

#26: Sorry, I usually try to be more astute. I didn't mean to imply that private sector health costs weren't a concern. But when was the last time you read about a storefront clinic being raided for defrauding a private insurance company? It seems to me Congress has enough on its plate with Medicare and Medicaid. If it can't manage those programs effectively, I don't see what expanded jurisdiction will accomplish.

I don't think it's as easy as you suggest for private insurers to past fraud costs on to consumers. The revenue and expense sides aren't that closely coupled. They're not cost-plus contracts, in other words. How much they can collect is limited by the marketplace (assuming there is a functioning one), and expenses are determined by negotiated rates and contract terms. They can't just pass on additional costs without being at a competitive disadvantage.

I think the opposite is true of public sector programs. They have a captive customer base, enormous pricing power vs. providers, and any shortfalls can be made up by tapping the general fund.

Mark Pepp (above) is right. A healthy nation requires a healthy middle class, and so far, there is no evidence a healthy middle class can be built upon a service economy base.

The problem with a service economy is that the wealth-creating jobs are at or near the top of the organization; the jobs lower down the ladder are simply support staff for the creators above. Even though those lower level jobs may be necessary, they are still treated as overhead for this reason.

In manufacturing and energy production, the wealth creating jobs are primarily at the bottom of the organization, and as such, can demand and sustain a generous wage. The pay pyramid of the organization begins with a higher base, and often ends up flatter, with a lower gap between the upper and lower extremes.

The lesson of the last few decades seems clear to me: A healthy middle class needs an economy built to create wealth from the bottom up, not the top down, and until this acknowledged, we'll just keep spinning our wheels.
Home ownership, having skills suited to a dying industry and not wanting to take a minimum wage job are definite factors.
Here in Italy, however, my take is that the last hired, usually junior in role and age, is the first 'fired' (if at all, based on their union agreement labor laws): sensible, no?

If there's one phrase that I hate hearing from out of work workers (no matter their age) it's "maybe I'll take a computer class or two".

As an employer, the majority of my down time is spent reading, blogging, and thinking about my business. I'm also constantly challenging myself with new software and technology, not all of it successful mind you, but it's vital that I never stop learning and trying new things. And when I hire, I look for employees to be better than I am at the things I can't do.

If you're looking for work (even if you're fully employed now) taking the random class is a very weak band-aid to your career. You need to show your employers that you're serious about what you do by devoting a serious amount of time to learning via accredited colleges and courses. Don't get me wrong, I value experience, but I've also seen too many experienced employees need an intern to help them use their email account or format an Excel sheet — the simple things matter, too. There is no such thing as "on the job training" anymore. In this economy, and in a flat world, you have to show up ready to go.

A lot of you are forgetting about the layoffs---even responsible, credit-worthy mortgage-holders (like me) are getting into trouble because of layoffs. I haven't been able to sell my home. I had savings, too (I'm still current on everything months after getting laid off in a mass company-wide layoff round) but my funds are running out. There's still no hiring in my field, which is shrinking, and I haven't yet been successful at switching fields. Seriously--it's awful out there. And people who think the only people in trouble right now are the ones who deserve to be are seriously misguided.

I would take an older, more reliable employee than a teenager any day of the week, and I say that as the mother of two teenagers.

Most teenagers are flighty. They will work until they don't need to, and since they don't have families to support, they are not as eager to be an employee that takes their job seriously and strives to do a good job in order to keep said job.

When I was a teenager, I once quit my job because it interfered with running track. They still needed a full-time employee, but the training and effort put into teaching me how to do the job was thrown away, and they were stuck still having to find and then train a new employee.

workerbee wrote: "The federal Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicare, Medicaid and Child Health insurance programs, estimates that the government loses 30 cents of every dollar to fraudulent practices in the medical industry."

If someone is commenting on health care and doesn't know that HCFA changed to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) almost 10 years ago, I have a hard time taking their claims seriously. Maybe your figures are out of date too?

Your data does not seem to be that usefull.  Younger people aged 16-19 may drop out of the work force possibly becuase they go back to school, or are on summer jobs etc.  In addition their total length of continious work may not allow them to collect unemployment as long as someone who has been working for thirty years straight.  Speaking on behalf of employers, would you rather retrain a thirty year old at a new job and hope you can get at least five years of work out of them or a 65+ year old a new job and will likely receive less than five years of a payoff before they reitre.  A more impactfull article would be to focus on the the recently college gradaute aged groups (20-24) and the near retirement aged group (55-64) rather than the two extremes.

Yes, younger workers usually have fewer "hostages to fortune" such as children, mortgaged houses, elderly relatives needing them in one location and such.  Debt is net of chains in this country, and one of the great myths is that a heavily mortgaged house is the correct answer when you are asked on a form: "Do you own your own home?"  No, your home owns YOU.

#10. Justin: Your attitude is the same attitude that Blue Cross/Blue Shield billing offices have had for years and years. When I was pregnant with my now 16 year old daughter, I received a bill/notice for an ultrasound exam that I supposedly had the previous month. Keeping in mind that this was 16 years ago, I thought that the insurance company would be glad to regain the almost 400 dollars that they were charged for procedure I never had.

To my shock, Blue Cross/Blue Shield told me not to worry about it, they would just 'write it off". I asked "if they wanted the paperwork and a statement from me, anything?" I was told, "It is just not worth it. It would cost more to process the claim than to let it go."

Imagine how many times my situation has been repeated...how many, many, many times!

Twenty-two states, mostly in the Old South and west, have right-to-work laws, which have the effect of discouraging union membership and keeping wages relatively low. New York is one of the majority of states that don't have these laws. Right-to-work are state laws that don't apply to Federal employment, which might explain why union membership among Federal employees is gaining relative to the private sector.

All accurate, especially re training for a new career.

At age 57 and 25 years of publishing-related experience, I was "restructured" out of my well-paying publishing job in 2006. I tried a different but related industry at an entry level position but was laid off after about a year and a half in June 2008. I have been drawing unemployment (stopping and starting) since then, spreading out the benefit with some part-time work. I reduced my expenses with a plan toward freelance graphic design and part-time jobs, but now it seems I am unable to secure high-deductible private health insurance due to age and MINOR pre-existing conditions. Now I need the unemployment benefit to pay for COBRA. (How ironic is that?) I continue to look for and apply for full-time jobs but the outlook is still bleak, and I was looking forward to the flexibility of freelance and contract work. So much for Land of the Free, Home of the Brave.

Debra (first post) is correct. I'll add that older workers are also less attractive because they'll be around for a shorter period of time. Given the time and other resources it takes to train someone and otherwise bring them up to speed, I'd much rather invest in a younger worker.

Incidentally, those younger workers are also much more "trainable". Older workers often have preconceived notions of how to do the job, which may not be compatible with the actual conditions in the company.

The fraud in doctor practices would never be uncovered by such investigative tactics. The problem arises from the what Medicare and other insurance companies have incentivised. Doctor services to patients, the actual effort and time we spend with patients, has been devalued to the point that, coupled with the administrative costs involved with submitting bills for these services in the byzantine US medical billing system, most practicing doctors have a hard time keeping the doors open. The answer has largely been to turn to the medical entrapanuereship that has been encourged by the medicare fee structure. Buy an MRI scanner, a lab facility, and outpatient endoscopy suite, cath lab, or operating room and Medicare will shower you with wealth. And of course all of the issues of over-utilization and self-referral become manifest.
If you want to "reform" the health care system, simply go back to paying doctors to be doctors. Pay them well, because their job is difficult, and pay them for nothing else. The disincentive of looking a patient in the face who has suffered from "to much medicine" will surely put the brakes on health care expenditure.
#19, I would have thought that life expectancy at 65 was the more important figure. I doubt that mortality between 18 and 65 is high enough to affect the trust fund very much one way or the other.

Is the issue really Health Care or is it Paying for Health Care?

I have heard enough about this subject alone, to clog and interfere productive thought processes for a lifetime; that is unless you have it in you to shake yourself free from all the constant dribble that we are bombarded with on a daily basis and realize that no matter how many layers you peel off an onion, it’s an onion all the way to the center, not an apple.
Health Care is not the issue or problem in my opinion; it is the method of payment for medical services that is! Examine what I am saying close and consider for a moment that in 1969 an outpatient self prescribed vasectomy with your family doctor cost $300.00 to $600.00 and in 2009 the same self prescribed procedure will cost you $500.00 to $800.00. Now ask yourself, why hasn’t the cost of this procedure skyrocketed, as in the costs of a root canal and crown on a molar for example? The root canal and molar costs ranged from about $100.00 to $200.00 in 1969 and now in 2010 the cost ranges from $1500.00 to $3000.00. Hmmm…….is there an explanation?
The reason I used this example is very important, they are medical procedures that have gone through very little change for the most part, and are generally self prescribed. The changes that have been made in my examples have decreased the actual surgical times by almost 75% for both procedures; allowed doctors too perform the procedures at the office thereby reducing staff by nearly half and with improvements to local anesthesia the doctor rarely has to make his patient incoherent. These are all examples of change that make the procedures more efficient for both the doctor and the patient, yet the dental costs have risen nearly 21 times higher.
From 1969 to present, what was the basic change between these two examples? If you hadn’t already known or guessed it at this point, it’s the way we pay for the two procedures! In 1969 it was extremely rare for a vasectomy to be covered under an insurance plan and even rarer if at all, that a root canal and crown were included in a dental plan, that is if you could find a dental plan, the patient was required to pay for it out of pocket. To this day the vasectomy procedures are rarely covered under insurance plans, but root canals and crowns are; thereby keeping the vasectomy cost in check but allowing for rogue casino’s (insurance companies) to give the doctors a big payout on the root canals and crowns; then slowly and steadily recouping the payouts with an increase in patient premiums, deductibles, and other shared costs that are unpleasantly similar to the slot machine formulas used in gambling institutions.
In the end, whether you think the method should be to rely on the “government to pay” or the “big private industry to pay” as if there is a noticeable difference between the two, the reality is either way, costs will continue to unjustifiably rise! Truthfully I have not found any form of commerce, that when free and liberated citizens relinquished and traded off (depending on insurance policies and bank loans) their responsibility rather than save their money and pay a vendor directly and in full, that the costs of products and services they were trying to get didn’t quickly rise disproportionately. The example that I gave above is only one of hundreds upon hundreds.
The way that the majority of people pay for health care (and many other goods and services) is fundamentally unproductive and deprecating to its core; just as an onion is an onion all the way to its middle. To what end do we continue to believe and buy into the fact that the onions (the hundreds and hundreds of different bank loans and insurance programs) we are being sold by the onion farmers (big government and the banking cartels) are apples.

OH MY GOODNESS!!! Reading one of the responses from JW, USA March 5th, 2010 9:32 am, I couldn't believe my eyes. JW said, "Steer clear of doctors if possible and no routine physicals every year!" AHH!!! My eyes are literally bleeding.

I don't know about your situation with the lump under your arm. I don't know what it felt like, and I'm not an MD yet. BUT (this is a HUGE but) I am almost certain that your doctor had your best interests in mind. I can't imagine that they wanted to poke and prod you for NO reason. Also, the reason for your routine physical is simply this-PREVENTION. This is how doctors catch prostate cancer, diabetes, AD, etc etc.

It is unfortunate that you think that physicians somehow want to do procedures for the hell of it. I've even heard the mantra, "if you don't take out a healthy appendix every once in a while, you're probably not doing enough appendectomies." (In this case, symptoms point to an appie, but it really isn't one... it happens on occasion.) But don't for a second think that you shouldn't go for a routine physical every year. Yes, there will be some hassles. Yes, there will be some false positives. This is part of the process of being vigilant.

RE: Travel up to Vancouver yourself and ask some Canadians if they'd like to switch to U.S.-style health insurance. They'll think you must be joking if you ask with a straight face.

Talk to them after they find out it will take two years before they get their procedure done and they'll be singing a different tune!

I am constantly amazed at the degree of cynicism expressed in comments to financial articles which might suggest that things are improving. It makes me wonder: are all these people obtuse or incapable of reading?

It is obvious to me that things are getting better when I look at the recent economic data. The temporary employment figures are just another facet of this.

Furthermore I am putting my money behind my convictions. I have invested in companies that will only do well (in some cases will only survive) if the economy continues to improve.

How many of the cynics are putting their money behind their convictions? For instance, if you think the economy is going to tank again, maybe you should be selling BofA or JP Morgan short. When the double dip arrives, I am sure you will do well.

Go ahead. Put your money down.
